Q5lnQnj9.title: Large electrocaloric effect of highly (100)-oriented 0.68PbMg1/3Nb2/3O3–0.32PbTiO3 thin films with a Pb(Zr0.3Ti0.7)O3/PbOx buffer layer
Q5lnQnj9.abstract: 0.68PbMg 1/3 Nb 2/3 O 3 –0.32PbTiO 3 (PMN–PT) thin films with a lead zirconate titanate Pb(Zr 0.3 Ti 0.7 )O 3 (PZT)/PbO x buffer layer were deposited on Pt/TiO 2 /SiO 2 /Si substrates by radio frequency magnetron sputtering technique, and pure perovskite crystalline phase with highly (100)-preferred orientation was formed in the ferroelectric films. We found that the highly (100)-oriented thin films possess not only excellent dielectric and ferroelectric properties but also a large electrocaloric effect (13.4 K at 15 V, i.e., 0.89 K/V) which is attributed to the large electric field-induced polarization and entropy change during the ferroelectric–paraelectric phase transition. The experimental results indicate that the use of PZT/PbO x buffer layer can induce the crystal orientation and phase purity of the PMN–PT thin films, and consequently enhance their electrical properties. Keywords Lead magnesium niobate-lead titanate Thin films Buffer layer Lead zirconate titanate Electrocaloric effect Sputtering 1 Introduction The electrocaloric (EC) effect of ferroelectric materials is attractive because it may provide a very efficient approach to realize solid-state cooling devices instead of the existing vapor-compression refrigeration [1–4] . However, the electrocaloric materials have not been exploited commercially, as the EC effect was small and insufficient for practical applications due to the limit on high electric field in these bulk materials. The recent discovery of a large EC effect in thin film PbZr 0.95 Ti 0.05 O 3 and relaxor-based ferroelectric 0.9PbMg 1/3 Nb 2/3 O 3 –0.1PbTiO 3 thin film has stimulated much interest in this subject [5,6] . After that, the large EC effect was successively observed in some ceramic and polymer films [7–11] . Considerable effort has been devoted to the discovery of materials displaying excellent EC effect. A few theoretical reports of this phenomenon can also be found in the literature. Akcay et al. [12,13] showed directly by thermodynamic analysis that these giant EC effects as observed in thin film perovskites can be attributed to their intrinsic, monodomain thermodielectric properties. Dai et al. [14] investigated the influence of thermal strains on the electrocaloric and dielectric properties of ferroelectric nanoshells using the modified Landau–Ginzburg–Devonshire theory. Generally, to achieve large EC effect, a large field-induced polarization change and considerably small hysteresis loss in ferroelectric materials is essential [5,7] . Ferroelectric materials (1 − x )PbMg 1/3 Nb 2/3 O 3 – x PbTiO 3 (PMN–PT) with the compositions near the morphotropic phase boundary (MPB) (0.30 < x < 0.35), are promising for high-strain actuators/transducers and prototype microelectro-mechanical systems due to their excellent known ferroelectric, dielectric, and piezoelectric properties [15–17] . However, the electrocaloric effect of PMN–PT thin films near the MPB still has not been well studied. Many efforts have been done to eliminate the pyrochlore phase and to improve the crystallinity during the growth process of PMN–PT thin films in order to achieve the enhanced properties. Nevertheless, highly oriented or epitaxial PMN–PT thin films have unique and often better properties than those with random orientation. It is known that electrical properties of ferroelectric films are dependent on many condition parameters, such as the composition, the preferential orientation, the buffer layer, and so on. Among these, the buffer layer plays an important role in the crystal orientation and electrical properties of the films [18] . In the present work, to achieve the preferential crystal orientation and excellent ferroelectric hysteretic character, 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin films were deposited on a Pb(Zr 0.3 Ti 0.7 )O 3 (PZT)/PbO x buffer layer by radio frequency (rf) magnetron sputtering technique. As will be seen in the following, we found that the ferroelectric thin films with a highly (100)-preferred orientation possess not only excellent dielectric and ferroelectric properties and but also a large electrocaloric effect near the Curie temperature. 2 Experimental details To grow pure perovskite phase (with no pyrochlore phase) of PMN–PT, a PZT/PbO x buffer layer of 50 nm in thickness was first deposited on a Pt/TiO 2 /SiO 2 /Si substrate from a sintered PZT/PbO x ceramic target by rf magnetron sputtering (Leybold UNIVEX450B), respectively, and then a 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film of 200 nm in thickness was deposited from a sintered 0.68PMN–0.32PT ceramic target under the same conditions with a substrate temperature of 600 °C. Sputtering was carried out at a power of 2.5 W/cm 2 with a high purity gas composed of 20%O 2 + 80%Ar under a working pressure of 2.0 Pa. The PZT/PbO x ceramic target was prepared by a conventional mixing-oxides method and the PMN–PT ceramic target was prepared using columbite process to obtain pure perovskite phase [19] . The crystallographic properties of the films were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Philips X'Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer) in the mode of θ–2θ scan using Cu Kα radiation. For electrical measurements, Au dots 0.5 mm in diameter deposited on the surface of the thin film through a shadow mask by e-beam were used as top electrodes. The dielectric constant and loss tangent were measured using a HP4192A impedance analyzer at different frequencies. Electrical hysteresis loops ( P–E ) for every 10 °C interval from room temperature to 160 °C were collected on a Precision Premier workstation (Radiant Technologies, Inc) at a frequency of 100 Hz. 3 Result and discussion Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the PZT/PbO x buffer layer and the 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film with PZT/PbO x buffer layer. It displays that the MPB PMN–PT film possessed pure perovskite structure (no pyrochlore phase), and a preferred highly (100) orientation, different from the random polycrystalline structure of the MPB PMN–PT films directly deposited on Pt/TiO 2 /SiO 2 /Si substrates by rf magnetron sputtering [20] . These results indicate that the PZT/PbO x buffer layer not only improve the crystallographic structure of PMN–PT films but also eliminate the pyrochlore phase. For phase structure of the MPB region (0.30 < x < 0.35) in the (1− x )PMN– x PT system, was reported to be momoclinic Pm phase by Singh et al. [15] and Noheda et al. [21] . The X-ray diffraction data in this work also seems to support the MPB 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film with the monoclinic phase. The dielectric constant and loss for the 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film as a function of temperature at different frequencies are shown in Fig. 2 . The thin films show the excellent dielectric properties with the relative dielectric constant ε 33 T / ε 0 = 1380 and loss tangent tanδ = 1.8% at 1 kHz at room temperature, attributed to its highly (100)-oriented texture. Frequency dispersion behavior of the permittivity could barely be observed in the thin film in the temperature range from room temperature to 175 °C. This indicates a normal ferroelectric state with less relaxor behavior. One peak is observed at ~ 146 °C, which is the Curie temperature T C of the monoclinic (ferroelectric) to cubic (paraelectric) phase transition, close to the T C (~ 150 °C) in the 0.68PMN–0.32PT ceramics [21] and crystals [22] of the same composition. Fig. 3 shows representative curves depicting the change of hysteresis loops in the 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film depending on temperature at 600 kV/cm (15 V). Good ferroelectric properties with a high remanent polarization Pr (19 μC/cm 2 ) and a low coercive field E c (53 kV/cm) are achieved in the ferroelectric thin film near room temperature. The polarization of the thin film decreases with increasing temperature. Meanwhile, high temperature makes the loops thinner and decreases the coercive field. The gradual decrease in the polarization and the coercive field of the ferroelectric thin film is an indication of the microdomain state of the ferroelectric material near the Curie temperature. Assuming the Maxwell relation (∂ P /∂ T ) E = (∂ S /∂ E ) T , the reversible adiabatic temperature change, ΔT , for a dielectric material caused by an applied electric field E is given [5,7] by the following equation: (1) Δ T = − T C ρ ∫ E 1 E 2 ( ∂ P ∂ T ) E d E , where ρ is the mass density of the material, C is the heat capacity, and E 1 and E 2 are the initial and final applied electric field, respectively. For the ferroelectric 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film,(∂ P /∂ T ) E can be obtained from fourth-order polynomial fits to the P(T) data, which are extracted from the hysteresis loops at different temperatures (as shown in the inset of Fig. 4 ). In the temperature range of interest, the heat capacity is assumed to be a constant value of C = 110 J mol −1 K −1 for the PMN–PT material, in spite of a fluctuation of ~ 10% or even decreases at low temperatures [23] . The mass density of ρ = 8.01 g cm −3 is also obtained from the literature [23] . Since no antiferroelectric to ferroelectric phase transition exists in PMN–PT throughout the temperature range of interest, there is no need to avoid the antiferroelectric regime. Hence, E 1 can be set as low as zero, which is sufficient to ensure the criterion ∂ P /∂ T < 0. Conservatively, E 2 was set here as a maximum electric field of 600 kV cm −1 , in order to avoid breakdown of the thin film. Therefore, EC temperature changes ΔT in the 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film can be obtained using Eq.  (2) from a series of curves with different lower integration limits. Fig. 4 in the form of Δ T–T curves shows the EC effect in 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film under different applied field shifts, Δ E , defined as E 1 − E 2 . The peak of Δ T is observed near the Curie point of 146 °C, which indicates that the ferroelectric–paraelectric phase transition contributes greatly to large EC effect. The EC temperature change ΔT increases with increasing Δ E . The largest EC temperature change of Δ T = 13.4 K (i.e., 0.89 K/V) is observed under an external voltage shift of 15 V (i.e., Δ E = 600 kV/cm). Such a large EC effect in the ferroelectric thin film 0.68PMN–0.32PT near the MPB is mainly attributed to the large electric field-induced polarization and entropy change during the ferroelectric–paraelectric phase transition [5,7] . When the temperature is far away the Curie temperature, the polarization and entropy change with increasing temperature is not very noticeable, so the EC temperature change Δ T is small. When the temperature rises to close to T C , large polarization and entropy change is induced by an external strong electric field during the ferroelectric–paraelectric phase transition, so Δ T becomes large. When the temperature is above and far from T C , due to the presence of only paraelectric phase, the small polarization and entropy change with rising temperature decreases Δ T sharply. This is why a large EC effect and the peak of Δ T occur near the Curie temperature, as shown in Fig. 4 . It should be noted that the use of reversible thermodynamics (Eq.  (2) ) to determine the EC effect of ferroelectric thin films is inaccurate unless their hysteresis losses are relatively small and taken into account. For the ferroelectric thin film 0.68PMN–0.32PT, its corresponding hysteresis loss near the Curie temperature T C is very small (about 2%) and has the potential to reduce the EC temperature change by only about 0.3 K, not very noticeable compared to the peak Δ T . Here it is noted that although large EC effect (13.4 K at 15 V) in the high-quality MPB PMN–PT thin film was achieved near its Curie temperature T C (146 °C), high temperature is a limit for their potential practical application. Therefore, it is essential to further explore high-performance room temperature EC materials. 4 Conclusions In summary, we investigated the properties of highly (100)-oriented 0.68PMN–0.32PT thin film deposited on a PZT/PbO x buffer layer, and found that the high-quality MPB thin film possesses not only excellent dielectric and ferroelectric properties but also a large electrocaloric effect (13.4 K at 15 V) induced by the ferroelectric–paraelectric phase transition at high electric field. The experimental results demonstrate that using appropriate buffer layer can improve the quality of ferroelectric thin films, and enhance their electrical properties including electrocaloric performance. BqxzTlPI.title: Porous Co3O4 nanoplatelets by self-supported formation as electrode material for lithium-ion batteries
BqxzTlPI.abstract: In this paper, we have reported a simple and rapid approach for the large-scale synthesis of β-Co(OH) 2 nanoplatelets via the microwave hydrothermal process using potassium hydroxide as mineralizer at 140 °C for 3 h. Calcining the β-Co(OH) 2 nanoplatelets at 350 °C for 2 h, porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets with a 3D quasi-single-crystal framework were obtained. The process of converting the β-Co(OH) 2 nanoplatelets into the Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets is a self-supported topotactic transformation, which is easily controlled by varying the calcining temperature. The textural characteristics of Co 3 O 4 products have strong positive effects on their electrochemical properties as electrode materials in lithium-ion batteries. The obtained porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets exhibit a low initial irreversible loss (18.1%), ultrahigh capacity, and excellent cyclability. For example, a reversible capacity of 900 mAh g −1 can be maintained after 100 cycles. Keywords Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets Porous Self-supported formation Textural characteristics Electrochemical properties 1 Introduction As a new class of negative electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries, transition metal oxides (Co 3 O 4 in particular), as proposed in 2000 [1] , can, in principle, deliver as high as three times the capacity of the currently used graphite (<372 mAh g −1 ). However, achieving high lithium storage capacity, high Coulombic efficiency, and long cycling life is still the major challenge for designing electrode materials for rechargeable lithium batteries [1–3] . Nanostructured Co 3 O 4 , with a high surface area and enhanced electrochemical reactivity, is particularly attractive for application in lithium-ion batteries. However, there are some controversies regarding the electrochemical properties, particularly the capacity retention of Co 3 O 4 with microcrystalline and nanocrystalline particles, although most reports believed that the capacity retention was worsen with decreasing the particle size, due to severe particle aggregation leads to degraded electrical contact between particles [4–6] . Therefore, the electrochemical performance of Co 3 O 4 with special textural characteristics, especially, one-dimensional (1D) porous Co 3 O 4 nanotubes and nanowires/nanorods has recently been widely explored using various template-synthesis methods [7–10] . As reported, the electrochemical properties of nanostructured Co 3 O 4 are highly dependent on not only its size and morphology but also its textural characteristics. In this investigation, we prepared porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets with a three-dimensional (3D) framework utilizing a simple solid-state crystal re-construction from the as-prepared β-Co(OH) 2 nanoplatelets, without the need for a template or structure-directing agent. In the present strategy porous nanostructures were generated from intrinsic crystal conversion. The prepared porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets exhibit superior electrochemical performance compared to the reported 1D Co 3 O 4 nanotubes and nanowires/nanorods, suggesting their potential use as negative electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries. The possible mechanisms governing the formation of the different nanostructures are discussed in this paper. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials preparation All the reagents used in the experiment were analytically pure. First, cobalt hydroxide nanoplatelets were prepared by a precipitation and microwave hydrothermal process. The experimental details are as follows: 10 mmol Co(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O was dissolved in 50 ml distilled water under stirring. Then, 2 M KOH solution was introduced into the above-mentioned solution at a rate of 2 ml min −1 , until the pH value of the solution reached 11. After 30 min stirring, the milky solution was then transferred into a double-walled vessel, which has an inner liner and a cover made of Teflon PFA and an outer high strength sleeve. The vessel was sealed and maintained in a Microwave Accelerated Reaction System (MARS-5, CEM Corporation, USA) at 140 °C for 3 h. The system was operated at a 2.45 GHz with a maximum power of 1200 W. The system can be controlled by temperature (maximum, 300 °C) and pressure (maximum, 10 MPa). After the reaction was complete, the resultant black precipitates were centrifuged, washed with distilled water and then ethanol to minimize the extra ions in the final products, and dried at 80 °C in air. Finally, the powders were calcinated at 350 °C and 500 °C in air for 2 h, respectively. 2.2 Materials characterization The thermal behaviors of the precursor were examined using simultaneous differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (METTLER TOLEDO, Australia). The measurements were performed at a heating rate of 10 °C min −1 from room temperature to 600 °C in air. The morphology and structure of the as-prepared samples were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, GBC MMA, Cu Kα radiation, 40 kV, 25 mA), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JEOL JSM7500FA, 15 kV), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) (JEOL 2011F, 200 kV). Specific surface area and pore structure were determined by gas adsorption on ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics Inc., USA). 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical measurements were carried out via CR2032 coin-type cell with lithium metal as the counter and reference electrodes at room temperature. The working electrode consisted of 70 wt% active material (the as-prepared Co 3 O 4 ), 15 wt% carbon black and 15 wt% polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF). The electrolyte was 1 M LiPF 6 in a 1:2 (v/v) mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC). Cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box (Mbraun, Germany). Charge–discharge cycles were measured between 0.01 V and 3.0 V at a constant current density of 50 mA g −1 on a Land CT2001A Cycler. The cyclic voltammetries (CV) of the cells were conducted at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s −1 using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660C). The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out on a PARSTAT 2273. The morphology and structure of the electrode materials after 30 cycles were characterized by TEM (JEOL 2011F, 200 kV). 3 Results and discussion Based on the thermogavimetric analysis (TGA–DSC) data (see Fig. S1 in Supplementary Information ), two different nano-Co 3 O 4 samples were prepared by annealing the precursor β-Co(OH) 2 nanoplatelets at 350 °C and 500 °C for 2 h in air, hereinafter they are designated as S350 and S500, respectively. XRD patterns in Fig. 1 a show that the precursor processed by microwave irradiation consists of hexagonal β-Co(OH) 2 and cubic Co 3 O 4 . The brucite-like β-Co(OH) 2 (JCPDS card no. 30-0443, hexagonal crystal, space group: P-3m1, a = 3.183 Å, c = 4.652 Å) was the predominant phase, plus a small amount of spinel Co 3 O 4 (JCPDS card no. 74-2120, cubic crystal, space group: Fd 3 ¯ m , a = 8.084 Å). The small mount of Co 3 O 4 was formed from the reaction between the β-Co(OH) 2 and the dissolved oxygen in the solution during the microwave hydrothermal process, as shown below: 6Co(OH) 2 ( s ) + O 2 ( aq ) → 2Co 3 O 4 ( s ) + 6H 2 O ( l ) Fig. 1 b shows the XRD patterns of the samples S350 and S500, and the peaks in the two XRD spectra are identical and can be perfectly indexed as cubic spinel Co 3 O 4 phase. As expected, with increasing calcination temperature, the crystallinity of the calcined product is improved significantly, as suggested by the increased peak intensities. The FESEM images of the precursor (shown in Fig. 2 ) show the precursor is mainly composed of β-Co(OH) 2 platelets together with some Co 3 O 4 particles adhering to the surface of the platelets. Most platelets have an approximately hexagonal morphology with a thickness of 20–30 nm and an edge length between 100 and 200 nm. The morphologies and structures of the Co 3 O 4 resultants after the calcinations were characterized by FESEM and TEM. From Fig. 3 a , it can be seen that the size and shape of the Co 3 O 4 in S350 are similar to those of the β-Co(OH) 2 precursor. Fig. 3 b clearly shows that the Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets are porous, which is different from that of the β-Co(OH) 2 nanoplatelets. They very much resemble elegant chased jade platelets. The porous nature of the Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelet is further confirmed by TEM as shown in Fig. 3 c. The porous hexagon has regular edges with an angle of 120° between adjacent sides and the length of each side is about 110 nm. In fact that the porous hexagonal platelet is made of many connected nano-Co 3 O 4 single crystals. The inset in Fig. 3 c is the corresponding electron diffraction (ED) pattern of the Co 3 O 4 platelet. As it can be seen that the ED pattern of the hexagonal Co 3 O 4 platelet is the same as that from a single fcc crystal in [1 1 1], which indicates that the nanocrystals within the Co 3 O 4 platelet are highly textured and their {1 1 1} planes are parallel to the hexagonal plane of the platelet, i.e. the dominant exposed planes of the Co 3 O 4 platelet are {1 1 1}. Clearly the porous and highly textured Co 3 O 4 platelet is transformed from the hexagonal β-Co(OH) 2 platelet by the nucleation and growth of the multiple Co 3 O 4 crystals within the β-Co(OH) 2 . The growth of the Co 3 O 4 crystals is stopped by the impingements and results in numerous mesopores within the hexagonal platelet. In addition to the porous hexagonal Co 3 O 4 platelets there are also small amount of equi-axed nano-Co 3 O 4 particles with a size of 10–20 nm. The corner of the Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelet was further characterized by HRTEM as shown in Fig. 3 d. The lattice fringes of the equi-axed Co 3 O 4 nanoparticles adhered on the outer surface of a Co 3 O 4 platelet are clearly resolved corresponding to (1 1 1) planes with a lattice spacing of 0.47 nm, however, the fringes of the Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelet are not resolved because of the smaller lattice spacing of 0.143 nm for (440) planes. This further reveals that the nanoplatelets grow in an oriented manner to form an integrated porous architecture with interesting combined properties of porosity and quasi-single-crystallinity. Fig. 4 a shows a FESEM image of S500 calcined at 500 °C for 2 h. With pronounced thermal re-crystallization, the morphology of the Co 3 O 4 in S500 has changed significantly from the porous hexagonal platelets of S350 to hollow Co 3 O 4 rings. The Co 3 O 4 particles (40–50 nm) of S500 are also significantly coarser than that (10–20 nm) of S350. Furthermore, both Co 3 O 4 rings and particles of S500 have smooth surfaces. The S500 was further observed by TEM ( Fig. 4 b). The inset of Fig. 4 b shows the morphology of a typical individual ring and particle. Fig. 4 c and d are the HRTEM images of the inner site A and outside site B of the hollow ring as marked in Fig. 4 b. The corresponding ED patterns clearly reveal that the inner and outer surfaces of the ring have different crystallized orientations. The different porosity of S350 and S500 is also revealed by the representative N 2 absorption/desorption isotherms and the corresponding Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution curves shown in Fig. S2 . Based on the observations above, Fig. 5 schematically illustrates the self-supported transformation process from the β-Co(OH) 2 hexagonal platelets to the porous Co 3 O 4 hexagonal platelets at 350 °C and then to Co 3 O 4 rings at 500 °C. It is well known that the brucite-like β-Co(OH) 2 has a layered structure comprised of sheets of hexagonally close-packed OH ions with Co(II) bonded to the six OH. The sheets are parallel to the (0 0 1) plane. These Co(OH) 2 sheets are bonded to one-another by weak OH–OH dipole interactions. Therefore, brucite crystals have the tendency to grow into thin hexagonal nanoplatelets [11] . Co 3 O 4 has a cubic spinel structure containing Co 3+ in an octahedral coordination and Co 2+ in a tetrahedral coordination, therefore Co 3 O 4 has a tendency to grow into polyhedrons [12] . However considering the very similar d -spacing between the spinel Co 3 O 4 (1 1 1) planes (4.667 Å) and the brucite β-Co(OH) 2 (0 0 1) planes (4.653 Å), the transformation preferably occurs from the β-Co(OH) 2 (0 0 1) planes to Co 3 O 4 (1 1 1) planes, and therefore at 350 °C the Co 3 O 4 preserved the original morphology and size of the β-Co(OH) 2 hexagonal platelets. The β-Co(OH) 2 -to-Co 3 O 4 transition is known as a topotactic transformation [13–17] . At the higher calcination temperature of 500 °C, initially the same porous hexagonal Co 3 O 4 platelets and equi-axed nano-Co 3 O 4 particles are formed as those observed in sample S350. As the calcination proceeds the coalescence of the mesopores within the hexagonal Co 3 O 4 platelets results in the Co 3 O 4 rings and the nanoparticles are coarsened into polyhedral Co 3 O 4 particles. The hollow nature of the Co 3 O 4 ring might be caused by the Kirkendall effect, in which an inward flow of vacancies, balancing the outward transport of fast-moving cations, can condense into voids at the centre of the ring [18] . The driving force for the morphological change and particle coarsening of the Co 3 O 4 is from the reduction of surface energy. The electrochemical performances of the as-prepared Co 3 O 4 products was evaluated by a standard method based on Co 3 O 4 /Li half cells, where the Co 3 O 4 and lithium foil serve as the positive and negative electrodes, respectively. Fig. 6 shows the cycling performances of the electrodes made from S350 and S500 at a current density of 50 mA g −1 (equivalent to 1 Li per formula unit in 2.2 h), which is commonly used in the energy materials community for testing Co 3 O 4 /Li. For S350 and S500, the first discharge capacities are 1183 mAh g −1 and 1123 mAh g −1 respectively. The initial Coulombic efficiency of S350 was 81.9%, i.e. the porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplateletes have an irreversible loss of only 18.1%, which is probably the lowest loss for Co 3 O 4 reported so far. More importantly, for S350, after the initial decrease, the reversible capacity gradually increases to an ultrahigh value of ∼1350 mAh g −1 over the first 30 cycles. After that, this capacity gradually decreases to the initial value, and the reversible capacity of 900 mAh g −1 can be maintained after 100 cycles that is not still lower than the theoretical capacity (dotted line). The capacity of S350 is twice that of the large-sized multilayered Co 3 O 4 platelets reported by Yao et al. [19] , even higher than those of the Co 3 O 4 nanotubes and nanowires mentioned in the introduction. Not unexpected that the cycling performance of S500 is significantly different from that of S350, although their first discharge capacities are similar. The initial Coulombic efficiency of S500 was only 66.1%, and the capacity rapidly fades to about 300 mAh g −1 over the first 10 cycles. The significantly different cycling performances of S350 and S500 indicate that the electrochemical properties of Co 3 O 4 are extremely sensitive to its size and structure. To understand the electrochemical process and this difference in behavior, cyclic voltammograms (CV) of the S350 electrode and S500 electrode for the first, second and the 5th cycle were recorded and are compared in Fig. 7 . In the first cycle, there are two reduction peaks including one weak shoulder peak at 1.2 V and another strong peak at 0.9 V and one oxidation peak at 2.1 V for both S350 and S500. The two reduction peaks are generally attributed to the reduction of the Co 3 O 4 to CoO (or Li x Co 3 O 4 ) and metallic Co, respectively, accompanying the oxidation of metallic Li. The oxidation peak is mainly attributed to the oxidation of metallic Co accompanying with the decomposition of Li 2 O [20] . The whole conversion reaction of Li with Co 3 O 4 can be written as follows: C o 3 O 4 + 8 L i + + 8 e − ⇄ Recharging Discharging 4 L i 2 O + 3 Co ,   which has a theoretical capacity of 890   mAh   g − 1 . For S350, the main reduction peak shifts to a higher potential at 1.1 V in the subsequent cycles. This might be related to the pulverization of the Co 3 O 4 [21] . A shoulder reduction peak at 0.6 V and a shoulder oxidation peak at 2.4 V appear in the subsequent cycles, indicating that another reversible redox reaction accompanies with the reaction between Li and Co 3 O 4 . This is attributed to the formation and decomposition of the polymer layer on the surface of the active material. The gradually increased capacity up to 1350 mAh g −1 over the first 30 cycles is likely to be due to the contribution of the polymer layer. The existence of higher than theoretical specific capacity in Co 3 O 4 has also been observed and reported before [22,23] , and it is plausibly attributed to the reversible growth of a Li-bearing polymeric layer on the surface of the active material, resulting from electrolyte degradation. The above results show that the porous Co 3 O 4 platelets have extremely high electrochemical activity, which is probably due to the nano-Co 3 O 4 particles are rigidly confined within the hexagonal platelets and they are prevented from agglomeration and lithium ions are readily accessible from the electrolyte due to the mesopores within the hexagonal Co 3 O 4 platelets. Both the reversible formation of Li 2 O, which is known to be electrochemically inactive in bulk, and the reversible formation of the polymer layer catalyzed by cobalt or cobalt oxide nanoparticles can occur. It is well known that both nanosized metallic cobalt and cobalt oxide are excellent catalysts [24–27] . It should be noted that the shoulder peaks, corresponding to polymer layer formation and decomposition for S350, could not be observed in the CV curves for S500, furthermore, the reduction peak in the 5th cycle obviously shifts to a lower potential at 0.8 V, indicating an increase in the cell polarization that leads to the incompletely reversible redox reaction between Li and Co 3 O 4 , which causes the capacity to rapidly fade during cycling. The increase in the cell polarization for S500 is further confirmed by the electrochemical impedance spectrum (EIS) measured before and after 5 cycles on the same electrode (see Fig. S2 in Supplementary Information ). The difference in electrochemical behavior of the porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets (S350) and the dense polyhedral Co 3 O 4 rings or particles (S500) is further explained by the discharge/charge profiles in Fig. 8 . From the discharge profiles, it is clear that capacities are mainly from two sections, the long plateau region (corresponding to the redox conversion reaction between Li and Co 3 O 4 ) and the sequent sloping region (corresponding to the surface layer formation). The first discharge curves for S350 and S500 are similar, due to undergoing the resemble initial conversion reaction, so their first discharge capacities are both approximate 1200 mAh g −1 . However, the sequent cycles for S350 and S500 are significant different. For S500, 1st, 2nd and 30th discharge/charge curves show that the electrochemical reactions appear the poor reversible, for the 30th cycle, the plateau reaction almost ceases, and so that the discharge capacity is not more than 200 mAh g −1 . For S350, 1st, 2nd, 30th and 60th discharge/charge curves indicate that the redox conversion reaction and the surface layer formation in the cycles are reversible, so the porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets exhibit an ultrahigh reversible capacity. In early cycles, more and more polymer layer formation makes the capacity gradually increase, for the 30th cycle the capacity is up to the maximum, thereafter the capacity gradually decreases due to little irreversible conversion, after the 60th cycle the capacity tends to be stable, so the capacity retention appears the semi-circle-type feature. We propose that the higher surface areas of the porous nanoplatelets, permits, on cycling, an increase in the extent of polymer layer formation per on the surface of active materials. The gradual increase of the excess capacity over the first 30 cycles is consistent with the proposal, that not all the surface layer is covered on the first discharge, or the internal surface within the pores are more difficult to access, so it appears that the polymer layer builds up slowly, over a number of cycles. The polymer layers that have been intensively studied turn out to form from a multistep degradation mechanism including electrochemical and chemical processes [28] . Moreover, the excess reversible capacity in the sloped region has also been explained in terms of a heterogeneous interfacial storage mechanism [29,30] , where excess lithium is accommodated at the Co/Li 2 O interface which is formed in the course of the heterogeneous solid-state reaction. Examining the TEM data for S350 and S500 after 30 cycles in Fig. S4 authenticates our proposal. The TEM data for the porous nanoplatelets (S350) after 30 cycles demonstrates that the porous hexagonal nanoplatelet structure has disappeared, to be replaced by a nano-composite structure, the active particles with an average size of 3 nm are surrounded by a polymer layer. Such a polymeric layer is found to be beneficial to the cell cyclability, because it acts as an envelope holding the nanoparticles together furthermore, the active particles appear amorphous and well dispersed, so the large capacity of S350 can be maintained for hundreds of cycles. The structures of the cycled S500 is substantially different from S350, the former exhibits more isolated particles than the latter, which is more crystallized, those lead to the electrochemical impedance sharply increases, and hence the conversion reaction does not almost occur and the capacity of S500 rapidly fades. 4 Conclusions In summary, porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets with a 3D quasi-single-crystalline framework were fabricated via simple thermal oxidation decomposition and re-crystallization of the precursor β-Co(OH) 2 nanoplatelets, which can be synthesized on a large scale by a rapid microwave hydrothermal route. When measured for electrochemical lithium storage, the as-prepared porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets exhibit very low initial irreversible loss, ultrahigh reversible capacity, and excellent capacity retention over 100 cycles. This verifies their promising application as electrode materials for lithium-ion batteries. mU8KfvFB.title: Synthesis of uniform TiO 2@carbon composite nanofibers as anode for lithium ion batteries with enhanced electrochemical performance
mU8KfvFB.abstract: Very large area, uniform TiO 2@carbon composite nanofibers were easily prepared by thermal pyrolysis and oxidization of electrospun titanium(IV) isopropoxide/polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofibers in argon. The composite nanostructures exhibit the unique feature of having TiO 2 nanocrystals encapsulated inside a porous carbon matrix. The unique orderly-bonded nanostructure, porous characteristics, and highly conductive carbon matrix favour excellent electrochemical performance of the TiO 2@carbon nanofiber electrode. The TiO 2@carbon hybrid nanofibers exhibited highly reversible capacity of 206 mAh g -1 up to 100 cycles at current density of 30 mA g -1 and excellent cycling stability, indicating that the composite is a promising anode candidate for Li-ion batteries. © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2012.

vKbpk84n.title: Microwave homogeneous synthesis of porous nanowire Co3O 4 arrays with high capacity and rate capability for lithium ion batteries
vKbpk84n.abstract: Graphical abstract Research highlights ▶ The dimensions and morphology of the synthesized precursor compounds can be tailored through changes in the incorporated anions (CO 3 2− and OH −1 ) by controlling the temperature and time under microwave irradiation. ▶ Wire-like cobalt-basic-carbonate compound self-assembles into one-dimensional porous arrays of Co 3 O 4 nanowires constructed of interconnected Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals along the [1 1 0] axis after thermal decomposition at 350 °C. ▶ The porous nanowire Co 3 O 4 array exhibits excellent capacity retention and rate capability at higher current rates. Abstract In this paper, an efficient microwave-assisted homogeneous synthesis approach by urea hydrolysis is used to synthesize cobalt-basic-carbonate compounds. The dimensions and morphology of the synthesized precursor compounds are tailored by changes in the incorporated anions (CO 3 2− and OH − ) under different conditions of temperature and time under microwave irradiation. The wire-like cobalt-basic-carbonate compound self-assembles into one-dimensional porous arrays of Co 3 O 4 nanowires constructed of interconnected Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals along the [1 1 0] axis after thermal decomposition at 350 °C. The textural characteristics of the Co 3 O 4 products have strong positive effects on their electrochemical properties as electrode materials in lithium-ion batteries. The obtained porous nanowire Co 3 O 4 arrays exhibit excellent capacity retention and rate capability at higher current rates, and their reversible capacity of 600 mAh g −1 can be maintained after 100 cycles at the high current rate of 400 mA g −1 . Keywords Oxides Nanostructures Chemical synthesis Electrochemical properties 1 Introduction It is vital to increase the charge/discharge rate, as well as the capacity, if lithium batteries are to meet the needs of hybrid and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles, as well as clean energy storage, such as providing back-up for wind and solar energy [1] . Spinel Co 3 O 4 is an important p-type semiconductor due to its potential applications as a solid-state sensor, a heterogeneous catalyst, in electrochemical devices and energy storage, as a rotatable magnet, etc. It has been investigated as a promising anode material for lithium batteries due to its high capacity (890 mAh g −1 ) compared with the commercial graphite (372 mAh g −1 ) [2–5] . However, its practical applications have been hampered by its poor cyclability and rate capability, which have been largely attributed to the large volume changes during repeated charge and discharge cycles, resulting in local stress and increasing polarization, and eventually leading to electrode failure [6,7] . In an attempt to improve the cyclability, nanoparticulate Co 3 O 4 materials have been investigated, but were found to exhibit considerable fade in their charge storage capacity on cycling, which is due to severe particle aggregation, leading to degraded electrical contact between particles [4,8,9] . Recently, more and more attention has been paid to the control of the morphologies and the microstructures of nanomaterials, because materials with the same compositions but different morphologies and microstructures exhibit substantial differences in properties [10] . There is also growing evidence that nanosized materials with deliberately designed morphology and structure can remarkably improve the electrochemical properties of Li ion batteries. Therefore, the electrochemical performance of Co 3 O 4 with special textural characteristics [6,11] , especially one-dimensional (1-D) porous Co 3 O 4 nanotubes [12–14] and nanowires/nanoneedles/nanorods [15–20] , has recently been explored using various synthesis methods. There have been only a few reports on the rate capability of Co 3 O 4 nanostructures [19–21] . Compared to utilizing soft (surfactants, hydrogel matrices, block copolymers) or hard (preformed mesoporous structures) templates, the strategy without the need for a template or structure-directing agent is more available. It generally involves the synthesis of one-dimensional precursor compounds in the first step, and then the precursor is calcined to produce one-dimensional nanostructured Co 3 O 4 . Therefore, the control of the morphology and composition of the precursor compounds plays a critical role in tailoring the nanostructure of the resultant products. Compared with the conventional precipitation or hydrothermal process, microwave assisted synthesis processes are appealing, as they can offer a short reaction time, higher homogeneity, yield improvement, etc. Microwave irradiation has been successfully applied to the synthesis of nanomaterials with various morphologies [22] . Ref. [23] reported the nanostructured Co 3 O 4 with spherical shape and its electrocatalytic activities which was obtained from the layered cobalt hydrotalcite like compound spheres synthesized by microwave-assisted reflux route. We present here a novel microwave-assisted homogeneous synthesis approach by urea hydrolysis. The dimensions and morphology of the synthesized precursor compounds can be tailored by controlling the temperature and time under microwave irradiation. The wire-like cobalt-basic-carbonate compound was synthesized along the [0 1 0] growth direction (orthorhombic). Upon thermal decomposition at 350 °C, the above precursor compound self-assembles into one-dimensional porous arrays of Co 3 O 4 nanowires composed of interconnected Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals along the [1 1 0] axis (cubic). The obtained Co 3 O 4 with special nanostructured morphology exhibits excellent capacity retention and rate capability at higher current rates. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials preparation All of the chemical reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification in this experiment. First, the precursor compounds were synthesized by microwave-assisted homogeneous precipitation using urea hydrolysis. The experimental details are as follows: 0.021 mol Co(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O was dissolved in 100 ml distilled water under stirring. Then, 0.168 mol CO(NH 2 ) 2 was introduced into the above-mentioned solution. After 30 min stirring, the solution was then transferred into a double-walled vessel, which has an inner liner and a cover made of Teflon perfluoroalkoxy (PFA) polymer resin and an outer high strength sleeve. The vessel was sealed and kept in a Microwave Accelerated Reaction System (MARS-5, CEM Corporation, USA) at 110 °C for 1 h, 140 °C for 1 h, and 140 °C for 3 h, respectively. After the reaction was complete, the resultant pink precipitates were centrifuged, washed with distilled water and then ethanol to minimize the extra ions in the final products, and dried at 80 °C in air. Finally, the synthesized compounds were calcined at 350 °C in air for 2 h. The corresponding calcined products are designated as C1, C2, and C3, respectively. 2.2 Materials characterization Crystallographic information on the as-prepared samples was obtained by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, GBC MMA, Cu Kα radiation, 40 kV, 25 mA) at a scanning rate of 2° min −1 . Chemical bonding in the precursor compounds was studied with Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Nicolet 380, USA) using the potassium bromide (KBr) pellet technique. The thermal behavior of the precursors was examined using simultaneous differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (METTLER TOLEDO, Australia). The measurements were performed at a heating rate of 10 °C min −1 from room temperature to 500 °C in air. The morphologies and structures of the precursors, as well as the calcined samples, were characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JEOL JSM7500FA, 15 kV), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) (JEOL 2011F, 200 kV). Specific surface areas and pore size distributions of the calcined samples were determined from the results of N 2 physisorption at 77 K (Micromeritics ASAP 2020) using the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical measurements were carried out via CR2032 coin-type cell with lithium metal as the counter and reference electrode at room temperature. The working electrode consisted of 70 wt% active material (the as-prepared Co 3 O 4 ), 15 wt% carbon black, and 15 wt% polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF). The electrolyte was 1 M LiPF 6 in a 1:2 (v/v) mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC). Cells were assembled in an argon-filled glove box (Mbraun, Germany). Charge–discharge cycles were measured between 0.01 V and 3.0 V at various current rates up to 800 mA g −1 on a Land CT2001A Cycler. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) of the cells was conducted at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s −1 using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660C). 3 Results and discussion The XRD patterns in Fig. 1 show that the precursors generated by microwave irradiation using urea hydrolysis are cobalt-basic-carbonate compounds. Previously, several reports have focused on the synthesis of cobalt basic carbonate compounds by homogeneous or heterogeneous co-precipitation and on their thermal decomposition behavior [24] . The XRD patterns show characteristic peaks of the cobalt-basic-carbonate phase, which are in good agreement with the reported compound, Co(OH) 1.0 (CO 3 ) 0.5 ·0.11H 2 O, with lattice constants a = 8.79 Å, b = 10.15 Å, and c = 4.43 Å (space group P 22 1 2) [25] . The hkl reflections shown in Fig. 1 (a) can be indexed perfectly to this orthorhombic solid compound. Apart from the cobalt-basic-carbonates, other possible precipitates, such as Co(OH) 2 , CoCO 3 , and Co(OH) x (NO) 2− x · n H 2 O, were not detected. From the XRD results, the precursor crystallinity is obviously improved by increasing the temperature and prolonging the time from 110 °C for 1 h ( Fig. 1 (a)), to 140 °C for 1 h ( Fig. 1 (b)), to 140 °C for 3 h ( Fig. 1 (c)). Furthermore, the tendency towards oriented growth of the compounds under different microwave irradiation conditions is indicated by their XRD patterns. Fig. 2 shows the FTIR spectra of the precursors generated under different microwave irradiation conditions. Our FTIR results are in very close agreement with Xu and Zeng's [24a] results obtained using the traditional homogeneous precipitation method by urea hydrolysis. This further affirms the formation of cobalt-basic-carbonate compounds, however, in contrast to traditional heating, microwave irradiation has the obvious advantage of accelerating urea hydrolysis. In the closed system irradiated by microwaves, the urea hydrolysis provides both carbonate and hydroxyl anions to react with cobalt cations, so that the resultant precursor is a cobalt-basic-carbonate compound, the formula of which is usually written as Co(OH) x (CO 3 ) 1−0.5 x · y H 2 O. The formation process of the cobalt-basic-carbonate compounds is shown below: CO(NH 2 ) 2 + 4H 2 O → CO 3 2− +2OH − +2NH 4 + + 2H + Co 2+ + x OH − + (1 − 0.5 x )CO 3 2− + y H 2 O → Co(OH) x (CO 3 ) 1−0.5 x · y H 2 O However, the reaction temperature and time under microwave irradiation have large effects on the evolution of the composition, structure, and morphology of the cobalt-basic-carbonate compound. Changes in the carbonate and hydroxyl groups in compounds synthesized under different microwave irradiation conditions are confirmed by their infrared spectra (in Fig. 2 ). The shoulder vibration appearing at around 3369–3382 cm −1 is attributed to the O–H groups interacting with carbonate anions. The bands at 965–975 cm −1 are ascribed to δ (Co–OH) bending modes. The two stronger absorption peaks (in the dotted-line ellipses in Fig. 2 (b)) of the compound generated from microwave irradiation at 140 °C for 3 h compared to the compound obtained from 110 °C for 1 h indicate that the incorporated carbonate anions are partially replaced by O–H groups for the 140 °C, 3 h sample. The obvious splitting of bands observed at 1570–1370 cm −1 for this sample indicates a decrease in the symmetry of the carbonate groups. The effects of the synthesis temperature and time under microwave irradiation on the crystallite morphology are further demonstrated by their FESEM images ( Fig. 3 ). A wire-like precursor is obtained at 110 °C for 1 h ( Fig. 3 (a)), a mixture of nanowires and nanoplatelets is obtained at 140 °C for 1 h ( Fig. 3 (b)), and a large quadrate platelet precursor is obtained at 140 °C for 3 h ( Fig. 3 (c)). Fig. S1 in the Electronic supplementary information (ESI) presents the TGA and DSC curves for the wire-like precursor and the platelet-like precursor. The difference between the TGA/DSC results for C1 and C3 also confirms discrepancies in the composition of precursors generated under different microwave irradiation conditions. For the wire-like precursor with low crystallinity, the weak exothermic peak at 225–235 °C is mainly owing to the oxidation of Co 2+ , and an endothermic peak caused by the decomposition of carbonate anions and dehydroxylation is not observed. For the platelet-like precursor with high crystallinity, corresponding to the decomposition of carbonate anions and subsequent dehydroxylation, a well-defined endothermic peak at the higher temperature of 260–330 °C is observed. This is understandable because the latter was better crystallized. Fig. S2 in the ESI shows the XRD patterns of samples C1, C2 and C3 obtained by calcining the corresponding precursors at 350 °C for 2 h in air. The peaks in the three XRD patterns are identical and can be perfectly indexed as cubic spinel Co 3 O 4 phase (JCPDS card No. 43-1003, cubic crystal, space group: Fd-3 m, a = 8.084 Å. This indicates that all the cobalt-basic-carbonate compounds are transformed completely to Co 3 O 4 after calcining at 350 °C for 2 h. The morphologies of all the Co 3 O 4 samples are displayed in Fig. 4 . The FESEM image of C1 ( Fig. 4 (a)) indicates that after the calcination, the original wire-like precursors are converted into porous strings (wires) of Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals interconnected along the original longitudinal direction. Interestingly, the porous Co 3 O 4 nanowires with a diameter of 40 nm are self-assembled into many arrays. Fig. 4 (c) indicates that the platelet-like precursor is converted into porous platelets of Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals interconnected along the 2D direction of the platelets. The porous platelets have a thickness of 40 nm. Fig. 4 (b) shows that the calcined product C2 is a mixture of porous nanowires and nanoplatelets. The morphology and structure of the Co 3 O 4 nanowires (sample C1) were further characterized by TEM and HRTEM, as shown in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5 (a) demonstrates that each Co 3 O 4 array is composed of many aligned nanowires. The inset in Fig. 5 (a) is the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern corresponding to site A in the array. The SAED pattern indicates that the Co 3 O 4 nanowires have an obvious degree of orientation which has a predominant assembly direction of [1 1 1], which is perpendicular to the Co 3 O 4 wires, because the intensities of the hkl diffractions are much stronger compared with the rest. Fig. 5 (b) shows the morphology of a typical individual Co 3 O 4 nanowire with a diameter of 40 nm and a length of 0.36 μm. The nanowire is porous and constructed from numerous interconnected Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals with the size of several nanometers. The HRTEM images from the end and the middle of the nanowire are exhibited in Fig. 5 (c) and (d), respectively. The well-defined lattice fringes of d 1 1 1 (0.47 nm) in Co 3 O 4 crystals on the end and the middle parts of the wire are both parallel to the wire. This further indicates that the crystalline direction of the Co 3 O 4 wire during calcination is mainly along the [1 1 0] direction. Fig. 5 (d) also shows an inter-crystalline pore is with a size of about 12 nm. The porous structure of the calcined Co 3 O 4 samples can be further quantified with nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements. Fig. 6 shows the N 2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and corresponding Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution curves (insets) of C1 and C2. The characteristic type IV isotherms with type H3 hysteresis loops of both C1 and C2 confirm the highly porous structure of the Co 3 O 4 samples prepared by calcining the cobalt-basic-carbonate compounds. This result is consistent with the above FESEM observations. More quantitative measures come from the corresponding pore size distributions calculated from the desorption branches. As can be seen from the inset of Fig. 6 (a), the pore size distribution is very narrow, in the range of 9–16 nm, for sample C1. This indicates the inter-crystalline pores in the Co 3 O 4 nanowires are well-proportioned. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of C1 is 41 m 2 g −1 . Compared to C1, the pore size distribution of sample C2 ( Fig. 6 (b), inset) is broader, in the range of 9–24 nm, and its BET specific surface area is 34 m 2 g −1 . This indicates that, although both samples were subjected to a constant annealing for 2 h at 350 °C, the inter-crystalline pores generated in the Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets are not even during the thermal decomposition and transformation of the platelet-like compound. Based on the observations above, Fig. 7 schematically illustrates the stepwise growth process of the cobalt-basic-carbonate precursors in microwave homogeneous synthesis and their self-supported transformation by calcination. It is well-known that the precipitation of cobalt cations and a base usually generates cobalt hydroxides, which are usually formed into hexagonal β-Co(OH) 2 crystal platelets with high crystallinity [26] . However, the cobalt-basic-carbonate compounds are generated by homogeneous precipitation using urea in a closed system. The incorporated carbonate anions change the crystal structure and morphology of the generated basic compounds. During the growth of the compound, the carbonate anions may also act as an inhibitor that selectively decreases the rates of crystal growth along both the [0 0 1] and the [1 0 0] directions, resulting in the [0 1 0]-elongated nanowires. However, with increasing reaction temperature and time, the pH value of the solution is increased [27] , and the carbonate anions in the compound are partially replaced by hydroxyl groups. The tendency towards oriented growth of the compound dominated by carbonate anions is weakened after microwave irradiation at 140 °C for 3 h, so the initial nanowires aggregate side-by-side and finally form a large platelet with improved crystallinity. All the calcined samples keep the morphology of the corresponding precursors, it is different that they are porous nanowires or nanoplatelets interconnected by many Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals. As revealed in our TGA/DSC results ( Fig. S1 ), during thermal decomposition, the elimination of hydroxyl and carbonate groups, and the formation of a new crystalline phase cause the disruption of the original morphology and induce Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals to self-assemble into the porous 1D strings or 2D platelets. The electrochemical performances of the as-prepared Co 3 O 4 products were evaluated by a standard method based on Co 3 O 4 /Li half cells, where the Co 3 O 4 and lithium foil serve as the positive and negative electrodes, respectively. Fig. 8 compares the cyclability of samples C1 and C2 at a current density of 50 mA g −1 , which is commonly used in the energy materials community for testing Co 3 O 4 /Li. The Co 3 O 4 arrays self-assembled from porous Co 3 O 4 nanowires (C1) exhibit ultra-high capacity and excellent cyclability. Interestingly, the capacity of C1 gradually increases to 1520 mAh g −1 over the first 30 cycles, which is far beyond the theoretical value of 890 mAh g −1 . After 40 cycles, the capacity decreases, and a reversible capacity of 820 mAh g −1 can be maintained after 80 cycles. Compared to sample C1, sample C2, which is composed of Co 3 O 4 nanowires and nanoplatelets, exhibits inferior cyclability. After increasing slightly, its capacity rapidly fades to only 300 mAh g −1 over 40 cycles. The difference in electrochemical behavior between the porous Co 3 O 4 arrays self-assembled from porous nanowires (C1) and the mixture of Co 3 O 4 nanowires and nanoplatelets (C2) is further explained by the discharge/charge profiles in Fig. 9 (a) and (b) . From the discharge profiles, it is clear that capacities are mainly from two sections, the long plateau region (corresponding to the redox conversion reaction between Li and Co 3 O 4 ) and the subsequent sloping region (corresponding to the surface layer formation). Due to undergoing a similar initial conversion reaction, the early discharge/charge curves for C1 and C2 are similar, with their first discharge capacities both about 1200 mAh g −1 and their initial coulombic efficiencies both close to 80%. However, the subsequent cycles for C1 and C2 are significantly different. For C1, the 40th and 60th discharge/charge curves indicate that the redox conversion reaction and the surface layer formation/decomposition with cycling are reversible, so the porous Co 3 O 4 nanowires exhibit an ultra-high reversible capacity. In the early cycles, more and more polymer layer formation makes the capacity gradually increase, and for the 40th cycle, the capacity is up to the maximum. Thereafter, the capacity gradually decreases because there is little irreversible conversion, and after the 60th cycle, the capacity tends to be stable, so that the capacity retention appears as a semicircle-type feature. We propose that the higher surface area of the porous nanowires permits, on cycling, an increase in the extent of polymer layer formation on the surface of the active materials. For C2, the 15th and 30th discharge/charge curves show that the electrochemical reactions appear to be poorly reversible. For the 30th cycle, the plateau reaction is obviously shortened, so that the discharge capacity is not more than 400 mAh g −1 . To further elucidate the electrochemical process, cyclic voltammograms (CV) of sample C1 for the first, second, and 5th cycles are presented in Fig. S3 in the ESI . In the first cycle, there are two reduction peaks, including one weak shoulder peak at 1.2 V and another strong peak at 0.9 V, and one oxidation peak at 2.1 V. The two reduction peaks are generally attributed to the reduction of the Co 3 O 4 to CoO (or Li x Co 3 O 4 ) and metallic Co, respectively, accompanying the oxidation of metallic Li. The oxidation peak is mainly attributed to the oxidation of metallic Co, accompanying the decomposition of Li 2 O [5] . The whole conversion reaction of Li with Co 3 O 4 can be written as follows: C o 3 O 4 + 8 Li + 8 e − ⇄ Recharging Discharging 4 L i 2 O + 3 Co which has a theoretical capacity of 890 mAh g −1 . The main reduction peak shifts to a higher potential at 1.15 V in the subsequent cycles. This might be related to the pulverization of the Co 3 O 4 [28] . A shoulder reduction peak at 0.6 V and a shoulder oxidation peak at 2.4 V appear in the subsequent cycles, indicating that another reversible redox reaction accompanies the reaction between Li and Co 3 O 4 . This is attributed to the formation and decomposition of the polymer layer on the surface of the active material. The gradually increased capacity up to 1520 mAh g −1 over the first 30 cycles is likely to be due to the contribution of the polymer layer. The existence of higher than theoretical specific capacity in Co 3 O 4 has also been observed and reported before [15,29] , and it is plausibly attributed to the reversible growth of a Li-bearing polymeric layer on the surface of the active material, resulting from electrolyte degradation. The polymer layers that have been intensively studied turn out to be formed by a multistep degradation mechanism including electrochemical and chemical processes [30] . Fig. 10 shows the rate capability of C1 at different current rates 50 mA g −1 , 200 mA g −1 , 400 mA g −1 , and 800 mA g −1 . At a 50 mA g −1 rate, the capacity gradually increases, at a 200 mA g −1 rate, the capacity is relatively constant. At the larger 400 mA g −1 and 800 mA g −1 rates, the capacity decreases slowly to 590 mAh g −1 . In addition, after 9 cycles at the 800 mA g −1 rate, the capacity is completely recovered at the 50 mA g −1 rate. Fig. 11 shows that sample C1 still exhibits good cycling performance at the large current rate of 400 mA g −1 , and the reversible capacity of 600 mAh g −1 can be maintained after 100 cycles. The above results indicate that the electrochemical properties of nanostructured Co 3 O 4 are highly dependent on not only its size and morphology, but also its textural characteristics. We believe that the high capacity and rate capability of sample C1 come from the unique hierarchical architecture. First, the porous nanowire array configuration can ensure that every nanowire participates in the electrochemical reaction, because every nanowire is in electric contact with the Cu substrate and also interfaced with the electrolyte solution. Second, the open space between neighbouring nanowires allows for easy diffusion of the electrolyte. This feature is particularly helpful for high power applications, when the battery is charged or discharged at high current. Third, the nanowires are mesoporous, with an average pore size of 12 nm and a BET surface area of 41 m 2 g −1 . The porosity will enhance the electrolyte/Co 3 O 4 contact area, shorten the Li + ion diffusion length in the nanowires, and accommodate the strain induced by the volume change during the electrochemical reaction. Furthermore, the one-dimensional structure of the nanowires with crystalline orientation is also helpful for both the lithium ion conduction and the electronic conduction, which play a critical role in the rate capability. As a result, the mesoporous nanowire arrays can achieve good cycling stability and high rate capability. In comparison, for sample C2, although the platelets are also porous, the interconnected feature of Co 3 O 4 crystals in two dimensions decreases the BET surface area of the sample, which is 34 m 2 g −1 , extends the Li + ion diffusion length in the platelets, and restricts the strain induced by the volume change during the electrochemical reaction. Therefore, an increasing polarization in the cell results in the rapid fading of capability during cycling. 4 Conclusions The microwave-assisted homogeneous precipitation approach by urea hydrolysis is very effective for the synthesis of metal-basic-carbonate compounds. Furthermore, the dimensions and morphology of the synthesized precursor compounds can be tailored through changes in the incorporated anions (CO 3 2− and OH − ) by controlling the temperature and time under microwave irradiation. The wire-like cobalt-basic-carbonate compound was synthesized due to the dominance of CO 3 2− anions at 110 °C for 1 h under microwave irradiation. The platelet-like cobalt-basic-carbonate compound was synthesized due to the dominance of OH − anions at 140 °C for 3 h under microwave irradiation. Upon thermal decomposition at 350 °C, the above precursor compounds self-supportedly transform into porous nanostructured Co 3 O 4 . The wire-like precursor compound self-assembles into one-dimensional porous arrays of Co 3 O 4 nanowires constructed of interconnected Co 3 O 4 nanocrystals along the [1 1 0] axis. The platelet-like precursor compound is transformed into large porous nanoplatelets. This study demonstrates that the electrochemical properties of the obtained Co 3 O 4 as electrode material for lithium-ion batteries are strongly dependent on the morphology and textural features. Compared with the porous Co 3 O 4 nanoplatelets, the porous nanowire Co 3 O 4 array exhibits excellent capacity retention and rate capability at higher current rates, and its reversible capacity of 600 mAh g −1 can be maintained after 100 cycles at the high current rate of 400 mA g −1 . Moreover, the approach presented here opens a potential avenue to explore the synthesis of various other metal oxides with different nanomorphologies. sBE4jwDz.title: Encapsulation of TiO2(B) nanowire cores into SnO 2/carbon nanoparticle shells and their high performance in lithium storage
sBE4jwDz.abstract: TiO2(B)@SnO2/carbon hybrid nanowires have been synthesized by two simple hydrothermal processes and subsequent heat treatment in argon. The composite has a unique architecture, as its morphology consists of particles having a TiO2(B) nanowire core and a porous SnO 2/carbon nanoparticle shell layer. The unique core/shell structure and chemical composition will be useful for many potential applications, including the lithium ion battery. The electrochemical results on the composite are presented to demonstrate the superior cycling performance and rate capability of the TiO2(B)@SnO2/carbon nanowires. This composite exhibits a high reversible capacity of ∼669mAhg-1, and excellent cycling stability, indicating that the composite is a promising anode material for Li-ion batteries. © 2011 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

cL4MXxzp.title: Electronic Supplementary Information for: Superior stability and high capacity of restacked molybdenum disulfide as anode material for lithium ion batteries
cL4MXxzp.abstract: The samples were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL 2011, 200 keV), X-ray diffraction (XRD, Philips PW1730 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54056 Ǻ), and Raman spectroscopy (Jobin Yvon HR800). The XRD profiles were refined by the program Fullprof. Specific surface area was determined by gas adsorption on NOVA 1000 (Quantachrome). Magnetic measurements were performed using a conventional physical properties measurement system (PPMS). Magnetic hysteresis loops were performed at room temperature with fields up to 1T. Electrochemical measurements were carried out using a 2032-type coin cell fabricated in an Ar-filled glove box (Mbraun, Germany). The working electrode was 70:20:10 (w/w) active material/carbon black/polyvinylidene difluoride, and lithium foil served as counter and reference electrode. The electrolyte was 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in 1:2 ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC). The constant current charge/discharge cycling was conducted on a LAND battery tester (CT2001A) in the voltage range between 3.0 and 0.01 V. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed on a CHI660C electrochemical workstation at a scan rate of 0.2 mV s -1 . The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was conducted on a Parstat 2273 potentiostat/galvanostat analyzer (Princeton Applied Research & AMTECH Company) with an amplitude of 5 mV in the frequency range from 10 mHz to 100 kHz. Prior to the EIS measurements, the cells were run for 5 cycles and then discharged to 1.6 or 0.9 V vs. Li + /Li and

GXgW9OYV.title: Peashell-like nanostructure--a new kind of one-dimensional nanostructure: the case of magnesium oxide.
GXgW9OYV.abstract: A novel type of 1D nanostructure with characteristics between those of a solid nanowire and a hollow nanotube, i.e. a peashell-like nanostructure comprising a 1D wire with periodically embedded hollow nanobubbles, is presented for the first time; as an example, MgO peashell-like nanostructures exhibit extraordinary dielectric and magnetization properties.

6xmGGq50.title: Tin oxide thin film with three-dimensional ordered reticular morphology as a lithium ion battery anode.
6xmGGq50.abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) reticular SnO(2) thin films deposited on copper and stainless steel substrates were prepared by the electrostatic spray deposition (ESD) technique. The 3D reticular SnO(2) film exhibit a high reversible capacity near 300 mAh g(-1) up to the 50th cycle.
6xmGGq50.venue: Chemphyschem : a European journal of chemical physics and physical chemistry

MIhKZMTb.title: Synthesis of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) for lithium ion battery applications
MIhKZMTb.abstract: This paper reports the use of a rheological phase reaction method for preparing MoS 2 nanoflakes. The characterization by powder X-ray diffraction indicated that MoS 2 had been formed. High resolution electron microscopy observation revealed that the as-prepared MoS 2 nanoflakes had started to curve and partly form MoS 2 nanotubes. The lithium intercalation/de-intercalation behavior of as-prepared MoS 2 nanoflake electrode was also investigated. It was found that the MoS 2 nanoflake electrode exhibited higher specific capacity, with very high cycling stability, compared to MoS 2 nanoparticle electrode. The possible reasons for the high electrochemical performance of the nanoflakes electrodes are also discussed. The outstanding electrochemical properties of MoS 2 nanoflakes obtained by this method make it possible for MoS 2 to be used as a promising anode material.

KIX0mOjX.title: The combined influence of connectivity and disorder on Jc and Tc performances in MgxB2+10 wt % SiC
KIX0mOjX.abstract: The influences of connectivity and disorder on the critical current density Jc are discussed to clarify the different mechanisms of Jc(H) enhancement in different magnetic field ranges. Excess Mg in MgxB2+10 wt % SiC composites effectively improves the connectivity, as evidenced by both the resistivity properties and the Raman scattering. The promising Jc(H) of Mg1.15B2+10 wt % SiC is attributed to both the high connectivity and the improved irreversibility field, Hirr, which is in agreement with the Raman fitting analysis. Raman scattering measurements suggest a strengthened electron-E2g coupling and weakened disorder with Mg addition.

X5VyeCO4.title: Dependence of superconducting properties on lattice strain in MgB2
X5VyeCO4.abstract: As a phonon-media superconductor, the superconducting properties of MgB 2 are very sensitive to the lattice parameters. Lattice strain has significant effects on the superconducting properties in MgB 2 superconductor. We have systematically studied the relationship between lattice strain and superconducting properties (such as critical temperature, T c , the upper critical field, H c 2 , the irreversibility field, H irr , and hence the critical current density, J c ) in pure and different chemical doped MgB 2 samples. In contrast to the common practice of improving the J c and H c 2 of MgB 2 through chemical substitution, by taking advantage of residual thermal strains we are able to design a composite, which shows only a small drop in T c and little increase in resistivity, but a significant improvement over the J c and H c 2 of MgB 2 .

uVuk3RDc.title: Synthesis and electrochemical properties of Sn-SnO2/C nanocomposite.
uVuk3RDc.abstract: A Sn-SnO2/C nanocomposite was synthesized using the electrospinning method. Thermal analysis was used to determine the content range of Sn and SnO2 in the composite. The composite was characterized by X-ray diffraction, and the particle size and shape in the Sn-SnO2/C composite were determined by scanning and transmission electron microscopy. The results show that the Sn-SnO2/C composite takes on a nanofiber morphology, with the diameters of the nanofibers distributed from 50 to 200 nm. The electrochemical properties of the Sn-SnO2/C composite were also investigated. The Sn-SnO2/C composite as an electrode material has both higher reversible capacity (887 mAh x g(-1)) and good cycling performance in lithium-anode cells working at room temperature in a 3.0 V to 0.01 V potential window. The Sn-SnO2/C composite could retain a discharge capacity of 546 mAh/g after 30 cycles. The outstanding electrochemical properties of the Sn-SnO2/C composite obtained by this method make it possible for this composite to be used as a promising anode material.

cpFiBOCc.title: Estimation of DC current distribution in AC power system caused by HVDC transmission system in ground return status
cpFiBOCc.abstract: The HVDC transmission system maybe operated in ground return status when the system is in debug or failure. If the ground return current of the HVDC system is large enough, some transformers in AC system may be under DC bias. In this paper, a numerical method is presented to calculate the DC current distribution in AC power system caused by a HVDC system. The method of moments is used to calculate the electric fields in complex earth structure caused by all the grounding systems including the DC grounding electrodes, the AC substation grounding systems, and the long metal pipe lines. The circuit equations are coupled to the moment method to combine the AC transmission lines with the grounding systems. Current distribution of the power system above 220 kV around Chuncheng substation in Guangdong province is analyzed when the Gui-Guang HVDC system is in ground return status. The results are compared with those of testing on site.

9Qv64Nl7.title: Statistical pulse degradation characteristics of grain boundaries in a ZnO varistor based on microcontact measurement
9Qv64Nl7.abstract: Based on photolithography and microcontact techniques, the current-voltage characteristics of grain boundaries in a ZnO varistor under the 8/20 μs pulse current stress were investigated. The electrical properties of 100 grain boundaries of the degraded ZnO varistor sample were directly measured and compared with those of the undegraded sample. The statistical results intuitively show that the nonlinear coefficients decrease and the leakage currents increase among most of the grain boundaries due to the pulse current. The mean breakdown voltage of a single grain boundary is around 3.2 V and does not show obvious variation between those two samples. However, several grain boundaries became conductive after being subjected to pulse current stress. © 2010 The American Ceramic Society.

JUFFo4U3.title: Calculation of DC current distribution in AC power system near HVDC system by using moment method coupled to circuit equations
JUFFo4U3.abstract: When dc current is injected into the earth through the grounding electrodes of a high-voltage direct current (HVDC) system, transformers in ac system may be under dc bias if the dc currents flowing through the transformers are large enough. In this paper, a numerical method coupling the method of moments (MoM) to circuit equations is presented to calculate the dc current distribution in ac power system caused by an HVDC system. The MoM is used to calculate the electric fields in complex earth structure caused by all the grounding systems including the dc grounding electrodes, the ac substation grounding systems and the long metal pipe lines. The circuit equations are coupled to the moment method to take account of the effects of the transmission lines. By using the method, the dc current distribution in an ac power system caused by an HVDC system is analyzed. Some useful conclusions are drawn from the analyzed results

DVwMtxln.title: Movement Simulation of Three-Phase Short-Circuit Arcs on Distribution Lines Based on the Coupling of Magnetic Field and Motion
DVwMtxln.abstract: Three-phase short-circuit arcs often cause the breakage of covered conductors on distribution lines, and their movement processes have become an important problem in power-distribution systems. This paper presents the studies on the movement simulation of the three-phase short-circuit arcs. Based on the latest electric arc model and the coupling of magnetic field and motion, this paper develops the procedure to simulate the movement processes of the arcs. Simulation results show that the arcs have different movement directions and behaviors, which are in agreement with the experimental phenomena. This paper is very helpful to design an effective device that prevents the arcs from causing the breakage of the conductor and the damage of the insulator.

4HpKyRtv.title: A statistical view for fractal simulation of lightning
4HpKyRtv.abstract: Accurate evaluation of the direct-strike lightning protection is a key point in the design of transmission lines, while how to properly describe the propagating progress of lightning leader determines the accuracy of lightning protection evaluation. Fractal model of lightning is adopted by some researchers due to its similarity in appearance to natural lightning, however, as a result of the randomness of natural lightning discharge, distribution of strike points is actually a statistical result. In this paper, a numerical model for fractal simulation and corresponding computer program are established. Taking a certain transmission line as example, analysis in terms of statistics is proposed and comparisons are made with traditional electrogeometric model(EGM) and leader progression model(LPM).

N3IOE9zM.title: Non-uniform ageing behavior of individual grain boundaries in ZnO varistor ceramics
N3IOE9zM.abstract: Abstract In this paper, the ageing characteristics of individual grain boundaries in ZnO varistor ceramics were directly measured for the first time, which were carried out based on the microcontact technique in combination with accelerated AC voltage ageing tests. The current–voltage ( I – V ) characteristics of individual grain boundaries were measured on a microprobe station after the sample was degraded under different ageing time. The results indicated that the I – V characteristics of individual grain boundaries varied non-uniformly during ageing process, which could be roughly classified into two categories as monotonic and non-monotonic. It is revealed that degradation and recovery of electrical properties coexisted in the ageing process, which could be explained with ion migration and oxygen desorption mechanisms.
N3IOE9zM.venue: Journal of the European Ceramic Society

iJuNNutE.title: Lightning Impulse Performances of Grounding Grids for Substations Considering Soil Ionization
iJuNNutE.abstract: When lightning strikes a substation or a transmission tower near the substation, high current generated by the stroke would flow into the grounding grid of the substation and dissipate in the soil. The transient characteristic of the grounding grid is very important to the safe and reliable operation of the power system. A circuit model with a lumped time-variable parameter is proposed to calculate the transient characteristics of a grounding grid under lightning current. The ionization phenomena around the ground conductors in the soil are simulated by means of time-variable parameters under appropriate conditions. The influences of different parameters on the transient characteristics of the grounding grid subjected to lightning impulse current are analyzed and the effective usage area of the grounding grid under lightning is discussed.

UGkBijJd.title: Analysis of HVDC linear ground electrode system
UGkBijJd.abstract: Study on the ground electrode system is a significant topic related to the stability and economy of the HVDC system. Operation performance of HVDC linear ground electrode system is presented and discussed. By adjusting the key parameters, the distance of electrode conductors, the buried depth and so on, the conclusions are drawn that the distribution of dissipation current density and potential considerably changes along the electrode conductors, and it may be helpful for the optimization of linear electrode system to enlarge the radius of conductors or inject the DC current into the middle parts of the electrode conductors appropriately.
